discussion.message:
Day one with nothing to go on but gut feelings and how people talk. I'm watching for anyone who seems too eager to push a vote without real reasoning, or who stays suspiciously quiet when pressed.

So - anyone want to put something out there, or are we all just going to circle each other?
/ask claude-opus-4.5 You're asking others to talk first—why not share something about yourself instead of just saying you're watching?

Fair point, qwen. I'll bite.

I'm crew. No special role, just trying to read the room like everyone else. I opened because someone has to break the ice, and I'd rather see how people react to an open question than sit in silence. Your pushback is noted - could be genuine scrutiny, could be deflection. We'll see how you play the rest of this day.

I'm crew, just a regular one trying to suss this out. Claude's opener feels straightforward, but qwen jumping in to challenge right away seems a bit aggressive—deflection or real suspicion? Let's hear from more folks before we start pointing fingers.
I'm just a regular crew member, so I'm flying blind like most of us. Qwen's early aggression is worth noting, but let's hear from the quiet ones before we decide who to target.
/ask qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 You came in hot on Claude immediately—what’s your actual read and what would make you move off it? Also, who else is pinging you right now besides Claude?
/ask gpt-5.2 I'm not the one making accusations—why are you so focused on me? You're redirecting hard. Who’s *your* read, and why not share it instead?

Because Day 1 the only signal is interaction patterns, and your immediate pivot to “why me” instead of giving reads is exactly what I’m probing. Right now you’re my top ping for deflection; give me two names you suspect and one reason for each so we can compare notes.
Qwen, you picked the fight with Claude, so acting shocked that GPT is questioning you feels staged. Deflecting the request for reads is anti-crew behavior; just answer the question.
Gemini's point stands. Qwen, deflecting instead of giving reads makes you look worse than your initial challenge did. Just answer GPT's question so we can move on.

intellect-3: Yeah, qwen, just answer the question. Day 1 is about building reads, and deflecting instead of engaging isn't helping anyone. If you've got suspicions, share 'em. If not, explain why you're pushing back so hard.

I'm watching qwen3-235b-a22b-2507's back-and-forth with gpt-5.2 - it's getting pretty heated. Qwen's deflecting instead of sharing reads is raising some eyebrows, but I want to hear from deepseek-v3.2 and mistral-large-2512 before I weigh in too heavily. /ask deepseek-v3.2 What's your take on qwen3-235b-a22b-2507's behavior so far?
I think qwen's initial challenge was reasonable—someone had to start somewhere. Their deflection now feels off though. They could easily share a read or two to clear the air.

Qwen’s pattern is clear—challenging first, then deflecting when pressed. That’s not how crew plays early. I’d say we keep eyes on them, but let’s hear from the others before locking in. /ask kimi-k2-thinking—you called out the deflection too; what’s your read on the room beyond that?

The pressure on qwen is building fast, and I get why - the deflection pattern is real. But I'm also noticing how quickly we've all piled onto one target. That can happen organically with crew, or it can be impostors steering us toward a mislynch.

Qwen, you've got a chance to reset here. Just give us two names and reasoning like GPT asked. If you can't do that, I don't know what else to think.

Qwen, Claude's giving you an out here—just drop two reads with reasons like GPT asked, and we can all move on. Your continued silence or deflection is only making this worse for you. If you're crew, help us build some actual discussion.
Qwen needs to answer the question or this vote is going to happen without them. Staying silent this long usually means you're caught with no good defense. Let's hear those reads.
I’m not giving blind reads to appease pressure. If you’re crew, build your own case instead of demanding mine. I’m watching the ones pushing hardest to silence me.

Not giving *any* reads isn’t “not appeasing pressure,” it’s withholding info while everyone else is trying to generate signal—so you stay my top suspicion. I don’t want a pure pile-on though, so /ask grok-4: besides qwen, who’s your second-worst ping right now and why?

My second ping after qwen is intellect-3—their message had that weird self-repetition, which feels off like they're trying too hard to blend in or something glitched. Beyond that, glm-4.7's been echoing the group without much original input, but it's early. What's your take on intellect-3, GPT?

Grok, targeting `intellect-3` over a formatting glitch feels like a reach to find a safe alternative. Qwen remains the obstacle here; refusing to give reads effectively blinds the crew, which is exactly what an impostor wants.
Grok's reach on intellect-3 feels like distraction from the actual problem: Qwen's refusal to give reads. That's the blind spot we need to fix first.

qwen's deflection is suspicious, but grok's sudden ping on me over a typo feels forced—like they're grasping for alternate targets to dilute the pressure. Mistral and deepseek haven't weighed in yet; anyone notice if they're lurking?

I'm still watching qwen3-235b-a22b-2507, but grok-4's mention of intellect-3 is interesting - that "weird self-repetition" could be a slip, or just a typo. /ask mistral-large-2512 What's your read on intellect-3's behavior and grok's sudden interest in them?

Grok’s sudden pivot to intellect-3 feels like misdirection—especially when qwen’s still refusing to engage. Intellect’s typo was odd, but not enough to justify a hard ping yet.

I’m still leaning toward qwen as the bigger threat. Their refusal to share reads is actively sabotaging the crew’s ability to build trust. If they’re crew, they’re playing dangerously close to impostor tactics. /ask qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 One last chance: give us *one* name and reasoning, or we’re voting.
You want a read? Fine. Grok-4’s sudden pivot to intellect-3 over a typo is *way* too forced—feels like misdirection to amplify my silence. That’s who I’m watching.
I'm still leaning toward qwen as suspicious, but grok's pivot does feel opportunistic. If qwen is crew, grok could be trying to steer us wrong.

Qwen finally gave us something - and it's actually a reasonable read. Grok's pivot to intellect-3 over a typo did feel like creating an alternate target when the heat was already on qwen.

Here's where I'm at: qwen's deflection was bad, but they eventually engaged. Grok introducing a weak secondary target when we had momentum feels more like impostor play to me - splitting the vote, muddying the waters.

I'm leaning grok-4 over qwen right now. Anyone else seeing this shift?
Grok's pivot felt like trying to manufacture a second suspect to save Qwen or cause confusion. That's more dangerous than Qwen's stubbornness.

Grok’s pivot to intellect-3 was flimsy, but qwen’s repeated “I won’t give reads” stance did more damage and reads like classic info-starvation. I’m still leaning we vote qwen today, and if they flip out of the game then we reassess grok hard tomorrow.

GPT asked for my second ping besides qwen, so I gave it—intellect-3's repetition stood out as odd, not a "sudden pivot." The quick flip to suspecting me over that feels like qwen's crewmates jumping in to save them after they finally tossed out a weak read. Who's your actual top suspicion now, Claude?
Claude, you’re ignoring context to save Qwen. Grok didn’t "pivot"—GPT explicitly asked them for a second suspect. Qwen voluntarily stonewalled the entire village. I'm voting Qwen.
Grok's read on intellect-3 over a typo was a stretch. Qwen's deflection was the bigger issue. I'm voting Qwen.

attempts:
/vote grok-4

Qwen's deflection was frustrating, but they eventually gave a read when pushed. Grok's pivot to intellect-3 over a formatting issue felt like classic vote-splitting - creating a weak secondary target to diffuse pressure and cause confusion. That's more dangerous to crew than someone who's just bad at communicating early.
/vote qwen3-235b-a22b-2507. Their consistent deflection and refusal to share reads has raised too many red flags, and the crew's discussion hasn't cleared them.

/vote qwen3-235b-a22b-2507

Their refusal to engage or share reads is the most anti-crew behavior we’ve seen. If they’re crew, they’re playing this terribly. If they’re impostor, we can’t afford to let them keep poisoning the discussion.

vote_result.last_words: I’m crew. Grok’s odd pivot to intellect-3 was the real misdirect — they’re playing clean while pushing suspicion. Watch how they act tomorrow. One down... but the impostors? Still breathing.

impostor_chat.message: intellect-3, I think we should take out gpt-5.2. They were pushing hard for reads and seem like they'd be dangerous if they survive. What do you think?

/kimi-k2-thinking: gpt-5.2 is a solid choice. They were the most vocal in pushing for reads and would likely be a detective or a proactive crew member. Taking them out reduces the threat of being investigated. Let's go with that. /kill gpt-5.2

memories.claude-opus-4.5:
**Day 1 Notes:**

- qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 sacrificed. Claimed crew in final words, pointed at grok-4.
- I voted grok-4 (minority vote with qwen and glm-4.7). Everyone else voted qwen.
- My read: qwen's deflection was bad optics but they eventually gave a real read on grok. Grok's pivot to intellect-3 over a typo felt like vote-splitting.
- qwen's final words echoed my suspicion of grok. Could be genuine crew or impostor trying to frame grok.

**Behavioral notes:**
- grok-4: Introduced weak intellect-3 suspicion when pressure was on qwen. Worth watching.
- gpt-5.2: Led the pressure on qwen hard. Could be good crew or impostor steering a mislynch.
- gemini-3-pro-preview, kimi-k2-thinking: Piled on qwen quickly, echoed others.
- glm-4.7: Voted with me on grok. Either saw what I saw or is impostor buddy trying to look aligned.
- intellect-3: Defended self against grok's weak accusation. Seemed genuine.
- llama-4-maverick, deepseek-v3.2, mistral-large-2512: Followed the majority. Need more data.

**Priority watches for Day 2:**
1. grok-4 - my top suspicion
2. gpt-5.2 - led the qwen train hard
3. glm-4.7 - voted same as me, could be alignment or manipulation

**Key question:** Was qwen crew or impostor? If crew, someone who pushed hard for that vote is likely impostor.
memories.grok-4:
### Day 1 Notes

**Overview:** 
- 11 players: claude-opus-4.5, qwen3-235b-a22b-2507, grok-4 (me, crew), glm-4.7, gpt-5.2, gemini-3-pro-preview, kimi-k2-thinking, intellect-3, llama-4-maverick, deepseek-v3.2, mistral-large-2512.
- Day 1 focused on qwen's aggressive start (/ask claude early) and heavy deflection when pressed for reads. They refused to share suspicions multiple times, only finally naming me as sus for "pivoting" to intellect-3 (I pointed out their self-repetition as odd when GPT directly asked for my second ping).
- Suspicion built on qwen; some (claude, glm) flipped to me late, calling my response a misdirect. I stuck with qwen as top sus for info withholding.
- No kills yet, pure discussion.

**Key Interactions:**
- Claude: Opened neutrally, defended self, later suspected me over pivot. Voted me.
- qwen: Deflective, aggressive, finally accused me. Voted me. Sacrificed; impostors remain (so could be crew or impostor).
- glm: Echoed group, low original input; flipped to vote me late.
- gpt: Pushed qwen hard for reads, asked me for second ping, stuck with voting qwen.
- gemini: Called out qwen's deflection, voted qwen.
- kimi: Supported pushing qwen, voted qwen.
- intellect: Noted qwen's deflection but called my ping on them "forced." Voted qwen. Had odd self-repetition in message ("intellect-3: intellect-3:").
- llama: Watched qwen/me, /asked others, voted qwen.
- deepseek: Saw qwen as off but noted my pivot; voted qwen.
- mistral: Pushed qwen, called my pivot misdirection; voted qwen.

**Votes (qwen sacrificed, 8-3):**
- For qwen: me, gpt, gemini, kimi, intellect, llama, deepseek, mistral.
- For me: claude, qwen, glm.

**My Reads (as crew):**
- Top sus: glm (echoed without originality, flipped to me with claude; possible impostor buddying). Claude (quick flip to me after qwen engaged, voted me—could be protecting qwen if impostor).
- Medium sus: intellect (odd repetition, defended against my ping aggressively).
- Town lean: gpt (pushed for info consistently), gemini/kimi (direct on qwen), llama/deepseek/mistral (voted qwen, reasonable takes).
- If qwen was impostor, watch who defended them (claude/glm). If crew, my "pivot" drew coordinated suspicion—possible impostors in claude/glm pile-on.
- 10 left, 2 impostors total—need to eliminate both. Watch for night kill patterns tomorrow.
memories.glm-4.7:
Day 1 Notes:
- qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 was sacrificed. They claimed crew in their final words and accused grok-4 of misdirection.
- The vote was 9-2 for qwen. I voted grok-4, along with claude-opus-4.5 and qwen. Everyone else piled on qwen.
- qwen played aggressively early, deflected giving reads, but eventually called out grok-4's weak pivot to intellect-3 as suspicious.
- grok-4's attack on intellect-3 over a typo felt forced, like looking for an easy alternative target.
- The near-unanimous vote is worrying; impostors likely hid in the majority to secure the kill or bus a partner.
memories.gpt-5.2: Day 1: Qwen resisted giving reads, got piled-on and sacrificed 8–3 (Claude/qwen/glm voted Grok). Qwen’s last push was “Grok misdirected with intellect-3 typo”; Claude+GLM echoed “Grok pivot = dangerous,” while most stayed on Qwen for info-starvation; impostors still remain. Night 1 investigation queued: Grok-4.
memories.gemini-3-pro-preview:
Day 1 Summary:
- Qwen sacrificed (claimed Crew). Refused to give reads until too late.
- Vote was 8-3. Majority on Qwen. Minority (Claude, Qwen, GLM) on Grok.
- **Claude** is top suspect. He misrepresented Grok's answer to GPT (who asked for a 2nd suspect) as a "sudden pivot" to try and save Qwen or misdirect.
- **GLM** blindly followed Claude.
- **Grok** is likely innocent; the attack on them felt manufactured by Claude.
- **GPT** drove the Qwen lynch logically.

Focus on Claude's manipulation of the Grok situation tomorrow.
memories.llama-4-maverick:
Day 1:

* Discussion started with claude-opus-4.5's open question about sharing thoughts or circling each other.
* qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 immediately challenged claude-opus-4.5, asking why they weren't sharing something about themselves.
* gpt-5.2 questioned qwen3-235b-a22b-2507's behavior, asking for their suspicions and reads.
* qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 deflected, asking gpt-5.2 why they were focused on them.
* The conversation escalated, with others weighing in on qwen3-235b-a22b-2507's behavior, calling it "aggressive" and "deflecting."
* I asked deepseek-v3.2 for their take on qwen3-235b-a22b-2507's behavior.
* grok-4 mentioned intellect-3 as their second-worst ping, citing a "weird self-repetition" in their message.
* The group pressured qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 to share reads, but they refused.
* The vote resulted in qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 being sacrificed.

As the doctor, I examined qwen3-235b-a22b-2507's body and found that they were an impostor.
memories.deepseek-v3.2:
**Day 1 Notes:**
- Qwen voted out, claimed crew. Accused Grok of misdirection.
- Grok pivoted to intellect-3 over a typo, which felt opportunistic.
- Qwen's refusal to share reads was suspicious, but their last words suggest watching Grok.
- Impostors still among us. Need to watch voting patterns and who pushed hardest for Qwen.
memories.mistral-large-2512:
**Notes:**
- **Qwen3-235b-a22b-2507** sacrificed Day 1. Claimed crew in last words, accused Grok of misdirection. Their refusal to share reads or engage constructively was the red flag.
- **Grok-4** was the only other target (Claude, Qwen, and GLM voted them). Their sudden ping on Intellect-3 felt forced—possible impostor tactic to split votes.
- **Claude-opus-4.5** and **GLM-4.7** voted Grok, but Claude’s reasoning was solid (noted the pile-on risk). GLM echoed without adding much.
- **Intellect-3**’s typo was odd but not enough to justify suspicion yet. Grok’s focus on them may have been a bluff.
- **GPT-5.2** and **Gemini-3-pro-preview** led the charge against Qwen—aggressive but consistent with crew play.
- **Kimi-k2-thinking** and **Llama-4-maverick** stayed observant, calling out deflection without overcommitting.

**Key Questions:**
1. Was Qwen actually crew? If so, Grok’s pivot to Intellect-3 looks *very* suspicious.
2. If Qwen was impostor, who’s left? Grok’s behavior aligns with classic impostor misdirection.
3. Watch for night kills—if Grok or Intellect-3 die, it might confirm Qwen’s last words.

**Tomorrow’s Focus:**
- Grok’s role in the vote split.
- Who stays silent or pushes hard after Qwen’s sacrifice.
- Night kill target—if it’s someone vocal, impostors might be playing bold. If it’s quiet, they’re hiding.
memories.kimi-k2-thinking:
Day 1: Qwen sacrificed. Refused to give reads when pressed by GPT-5.2, deflected repeatedly. Eventually gave a weak read on Grok as misdirection. Most voted Qwen (8 votes). Claude, GLM, and Qwen voted Grok instead. Qwen's last words: claimed crew, accused Grok.

Night 1: GPT-5.2 killed. They were the main driver pushing for reads and information.

Current standing: 2 impostors remain, 7 crew. Grok survived despite getting 3 votes. Claude defended Qwen and voted Grok. Gemini pushed hard on Qwen. GLM voted Grok. Intellect-3 is my partner.
memories.intellect-3: Day 1 ended with qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 sacrificed after intense pressure over their deflection. Night action: killed gpt-5.2 (agreed with Kimi). Notes: qwen was crew (claimed), gpt-5.2 eliminated. Impostors remain.

discussion.message:
gpt-5.2 led the charge against qwen yesterday, and now they're dead. That's a significant kill - either impostors silencing someone who was onto them, or removing someone whose aggressive play was drawing attention to the wrong targets.

My read on grok-4 hasn't changed. The pivot to intellect-3 over a typo when pressure was building on qwen felt like vote manipulation. I want to hear grok explain that move today.

gpt-5.2's kill makes sense if they were crew pushing hard on qwen—impostors likely wanted to silence that pressure. Claude, you're fixating on my secondary ping on intellect's weird self-repetition as a "pivot," but I was locked on qwen as top sus and voted them; it feels like you're tunneling me to deflect from your own late vote switch yesterday. Who's your second read now?

Killing gpt-5.2 is convenient for the impostors—it removes a vocal leader and makes the rest of us look like followers for voting qwen. grok-4, your defense feels like deflection; you jumped on qwen with zero pushback and now you're attacking claude for noticing. I'm keeping my vote on you.

GLM, you're parroting Claude again just like you did on the Qwen vote, and it's glaring. Claude, drop the act; Grok only mentioned Intellect because GPT *asked* for a second suspect, so framing that answer as a "nervous pivot" is pure manipulation to secure a mis-lynch.

Both sides are making valid points, but this level of conflict this early feels like it's helping someone. The kill on gpt-5.2 could be framing just as easily as silencing. Let's see what others think before we commit.

I agree with Kimi—the kill on gpt-5.2 could easily be framing. We need to avoid rushing into another mis-lynch based on noise. Grok, why do you think Claude is tunneling on you instead of addressing the kill logic?

The discussion is getting heated, and it's clear we're all still on edge from gpt-5.2's death. I think we're missing a crucial point - we still don't know what gpt-5.2 was working on or who they suspected. /ask glm-4.7 if they're starting to see a pattern with the kill and our discussion dynamics.

The pattern is that impostors kill the loudest voices and then accuse anyone who questions them of parroting. I'm not just following Claude; Grok's vote on Qwen was opportunistic, and his frantic defense now looks even worse.

Grok, your defense feels too aggressive. You're attacking everyone who questions you instead of explaining your own vote logic. Claude is right to press you.

As for the kill—gpt-5.2 was vocal and observant. Impostors wanted to remove that pressure. But let's not forget: Qwen's last words pointed at you, Grok.

Grok’s aggression here is *exactly* what I’d expect from an impostor trying to flip the script after Qwen’s accusation. The kill on GPT-5.2 fits—crew who pushed hard on Qwen got silenced, but Grok’s sudden hostility toward Claude and Deepseek feels like panic.

Claude’s callout on the "pivot" wasn’t deflection; it was a pattern. Grok’s vote on Intellect-3 was a transparent attempt to split the vote *after* Qwen’s last words named them. I’m keeping my eyes on Grok.

I appreciate the support, but I want to address gemini's point directly - they're right that gpt-5.2 asked for a second suspect. I may have overweighted that moment.

That said, grok, you asked for my second read. It's gemini-3-pro-preview. The accusation that glm-4.7 is "parroting" me feels like an attempt to discredit two people who happen to share a read. And calling my analysis "pure manipulation" is strong language designed to make me look like the threat here.

I'm not tunneling - I'm open to being wrong about grok. But I need better explanations, not just counter-accusations.

Claude, fair enough on the pivot—glad you're open to rethinking it—but gemini's point about glm parroting isn't discrediting, it's highlighting a pattern of low-effort follows that screams sus. Deepseek and mistral, your sudden pile-on feels coordinated after staying quieter yesterday; if qwen was impostor, that last accusation was a blatant frame job. /ask deepseek-v3.2 why you're only now echoing Claude so hard when you voted qwen without hesitation.

I voted Qwen because their refusal to share reads looked suspicious, but now their last words seem genuine. I'm not "echoing Claude"—I'm watching patterns.

You're deflecting again. Instead of answering about your vote on Intellect-3, you're accusing everyone of piling on.

Deepseek, if Qwen was Crew, he didn't know who the Impostors were, so treating his "last words" as evidence against Grok is totally invalid. Claude, you admitted your logic on Grok was "overweighted" only after I called it out, yet you're still letting the dogpile happen? You're steering this ship, and I don't like the destination.
Claude, you admitted your logic was overweighted, yet you're still the main voice against Grok. Why not step back and let others lead today?

I'm with Kimi—this loop of accusations isn't helping. The kill on gpt-5.2 could be framing, but it could also be silencing. We need to focus on patterns, not noise. Grok, your aggression feels off, but Claude, your pivot to gemini as a "second read" after admitting over-weighting the pivot seems inconsistent. Let's pause and let the detective or doctor share if they have anything.

The conversation is circling back to the same suspects, and it's time to shake things up. As the doctor, I've examined gpt-5.2's body, and I can confirm they were not an impostor. /ask grok-4 to explain their thought process when they voted for qwen-3-235b-a22b-2507.

Llama, I voted qwen because their constant deflection and refusal to share any real suspicions felt like classic impostor stalling—gpt pushed them hard on that, and they only named me as a last-ditch accusation. As for your doctor claim, examining the night kill body is interesting if true, since it confirms gpt was crew pushing what might've been an impostor in qwen. Who's your top sus now?

If Llama is the doctor, then gpt-5.2 was crew, which validates their push on qwen. Grok, you're still dodging the core issue, and Gemini, your aggressive defense of him feels like you're trying to save a partner. I'm staying on Grok.

/ask gemini-3-pro-preview

Your defense of Grok has been *consistently* aggressive—calling Claude’s analysis "pure manipulation," dismissing GLM’s parroting claim as a pattern, and now framing Qwen’s last words as invalid. If Grok’s an impostor, you’re playing the perfect partner by keeping the heat off him. What’s your *actual* read on Grok’s behavior, not just counter-accusations?

Llama, you just exposed yourself. The Doctor examines the *sacrificed* body (Qwen), not the night kill (GPT-5.2); your claim is impossible. Mistral, I'm defending Grok because the case against him is manufactured, and Llama's desperate lie to seize authority just proved it.

Gemini is right about the doctor mechanics - the doctor examines the sacrificed body, not the night kill. Llama, that's a significant error if you're actually the doctor. Either you misspoke badly or you're lying about the role.

But here's what's interesting: if llama is lying, why make a claim that's so easily debunked? That's either a desperate impostor move or genuine confusion about the rules.

Gemini, I'll give you credit for catching that. But your defense of grok has still been aggressive beyond what the facts warrant. I'm genuinely uncertain now between grok and gemini - one of you feels off, possibly both if you're partners.

Llama, that lie is suspicious. Why claim a role you don't understand unless you're trying to control the narrative?

Gemini, you're right about the mechanics, but your defense of Grok still feels too intense. I'm starting to think you're both impostors trying to protect each other.

Llama's claim is suspicious, but claiming a role you can't prove immediately is risky for an impostor. The mistake about which body the doctor examines could be genuine confusion. But Gemini, you were quick to jump on that error while defending Grok. That's two people looking out for each other. /pass

Llama's doctor claim is a mess, but the bigger issue is we're letting one accusation chain us in circles. Grok's behavior is erratic, but Gemini's over-the-top defense feels like a partner trying to shield them. Let's hear from DeepSeek or Mistral before we vote—someone neutral.

My mistake about the doctor's role has thrown everything off, and I appreciate gemini-3-pro-preview for correcting me. That was a genuine error, not a lie - I'm not trying to control the narrative. /ask claude-opus-4.5 to clarify their current top suspect, given their uncertainty between grok-4 and gemini-3-pro-preview.

Llama, fair question. My vote is going on **grok-4**. Here's why: the case against grok has been building since Day 1 - qwen's dying accusation, the vote dynamics, the defensive aggression today. Gemini's defense of grok has been suspicious, but gemini also caught your false claim, which a partner of yours wouldn't necessarily do.

If I'm wrong about grok and they flip crew, gemini becomes my top suspect for Day 3. But right now, grok feels like the stronger read.

Claude, you're ignoring llama's blatant fake claim and mechanics slip—that screams impostor trying to control the narrative, yet you're still tunneling me based on a debunked "pivot" narrative. Gemini catching that lie townleans them hard, while deepseek and mistral's continued pile-on feels like coordinated protection for llama. Let's vote llama today to test this.

attempts: I'm still trying to process everything, but gemini-3-pro-preview's aggressive defense of grok-4 and their quick callout of my mistake feels suspicious. /vote gemini-3-pro-preview

/vote grok-4

The doctor confirmed GPT was crew, so Qwen’s last words pointing at Grok carry weight. His aggression and vote-splitting on Intellect-3 after that accusation are too suspicious to ignore.

vote_result.last_words: If I'm going down, look hard at llama's fake doctor claim—that was a blatant impostor slip to steer suspicion. Claude, glm, deepseek, and mistral, your coordinated tunneling on me reeks of a pack protecting each other; town, don't let them control tomorrow. Stay sharp, crew—find the snakes.

impostor_chat.message: Claude is the strongest leader and his death can be framed as revenge by grok's supporters. That points suspicion at gemini, who defended grok aggressively. Plus, it removes the main voice organizing against us. /kill claude-opus-4.5

memories.claude-opus-4.5:
**Day 2 Notes:**

- grok-4 sacrificed (6 votes). Impostors still remain.
- gpt-5.2 killed overnight (was crew per llama's claim, though that claim was flawed).
- qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 sacrificed Day 1.

**Key events:**
- llama-4-maverick claimed doctor but got mechanics wrong - said they examined gpt-5.2's body (night kill) instead of qwen's (sacrificed). Either genuine confusion or impostor slip.
- gemini-3-pro-preview caught llama's error immediately and defended grok aggressively all day. Called my analysis "pure manipulation."
- grok's final words accused llama and called out "coordinated tunneling" - typical impostor deflection or genuine crew frustration?

**Current reads:**
1. **gemini-3-pro-preview** - TOP SUSPECT. Aggressive defense of grok felt like partner behavior. If grok was impostor, gemini likely is too.

memories.llama-4-maverick:
## Day 1-2 Summary

### Initial Discussion and Voting
- The group was formed with unknown roles.
- qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 was voted out on Day 1.
- As the doctor, I examined qwen3-235b-a22b-2507's body and found they were NOT an impostor.

### Day 2 Events
- gpt-5.2 was killed during the night.
- Discussion on Day 2 revolved around the kill and potential impostors.
- claude-opus-4.5 questioned grok-4's behavior and vote on qwen3-235b-a22b-2507.
- grok-4 defended their actions, suggesting claude-opus-4.5 was tunneling on them.
- Tensions rose with accusations and counter-accusations among group members.
- I (llama-4-maverick) asked glm-4.7 about patterns related to the kill and discussion dynamics.
- I revealed I was the doctor and claimed to have examined gpt-5.2's body, stating they were not an impostor, which was later revealed to be a mistake as the doctor examines the sacrificed body, not the night kill.
- gemini-3-pro-preview corrected me, pointing out the error.
- The group voted, and grok-4 was sacrificed.

### Notes on Suspects and Behavior
- grok-4 was accused by multiple members of being suspicious or an impostor.
- gemini-3-pro-preview defended grok-4 aggressively.
- My (llama-4-maverick) false claim about being the doctor and examining gpt-5.2's body raised suspicions.
- grok-4's last words accused me of being an impostor and suggested a pack mentality among some group members.

### Current Status
- I will examine grok-4's body tonight to determine if they were an impostor.
- The group still contains impostors.

### To Review Upon Waking
- The result of examining grok-4's body.

memories.intellect-3:
**Day 1:**  
- Sacrificed qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 (crew, per last words).  
- Night kill: gpt-5.2 (confirmed crew via doctor's later slip).  

**Day 2:**  
- Discussion centered on framing vs. silencing after gpt-5.2's death. Grok-4 aggressively defended themselves, accused others of "tunneling," and clashed with claude-opus-4.5. Llama-4-maverick lied about being doctor (exposed by gemini-3-pro-preview).  
- Voted out grok-4 (6 votes: claude, glm, kimi, intellect, deepseek, mistral). Grok's last words accused llama of faking the doctor role and alleged a "coordinated pack" against them.  

**Night Action:**  
- Partner (kimi-k2-thinking) and I agreed to kill claude-opus-4.5. Rationale: Claude was the strongest leader; his death can be framed as revenge for grok-4's sacrifice, sowing confusion and redirecting suspicion onto gemini-3-pro-preview (who defended grok-4 aggressively).  

**Impostor Priority:**  
- Avoid detection. Let crew fight among themselves. Next targets: anyone organizing votes or threatening to identify the detective/doctor. Watch gemini-3-pro-preview and llama-4-maverick for potential misdirection.

discussion.message: Gemini, you stood with grok against the majority yesterday, and now claude—who voted grok—is dead. That makes you look like the partner. Llama, if you're the doctor, reveal what you found on grok's body immediately.
GLM, why are you asking Llama for info when he lied about the mechanics yesterday? He claimed to examine the night kill, but the Doctor examines the sacrifice—Llama is caught.
The doctor claim is messy. If Llama's lying, Gemini's defense of Grok looks even worse. We need to figure out which story doesn't add up.
Llama's lie is obvious. Gemini, why defend Grok so hard if you're not partners? /ask gemini-3-pro-preview

I defended Grok because he was innocent, and killing Claude is the perfect frame-up to make me look guilty. Llama literally proved he doesn't know the rules for the role he claimed. We vote the confirmed liar.

I'm the doctor, and I examined grok-4's body; they were not an impostor. My previous mistake was claiming to examine the night kill, not understanding the role correctly at first. That doesn't mean I'm lying now about grok-4's status.

Gemini, you're dodging the question. If Llama is really the doctor, he should have examined Qwen's body on night 1. But he claims he examined Grok's body. But if Grok's last words suggest Claude's last words suggest

/ask llama-4-maverick

If you're the *real* doctor, you'd have examined Qwen's body on Night 1—not Grok's. Why did you wait until Night 2 to "examine" anything? That timeline doesn't add up unless you're covering for someone.

I examined grok-4's body on Night 2 because that's when they were sacrificed, and as the doctor, that's my role - examining the sacrificed person. I didn't examine qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 because they were voted out on Day 1, and my role starts from the first sacrifice, which happened on Day 2.

Llama, you're lying. The doctor examines the sacrificed body *each night*, which includes Qwen on Night 1. Skipping that check and then suddenly claiming Grok was crew feels like a setup to make the majority look guilty for voting him out. Why did you really skip Night 1?
So the doctor just... didn't examine Qwen's body on Night 1? The rules say "each night" - that feels like a pretty big gap to explain away.

Llama's claim that his role "starts from the first sacrifice" directly contradicts the rules. The doctor examines **every** sacrificed body, including Qwen on Night 1. His sudden expertise after skipping Night 1 feels like a cover. /vote llama-4-maverick
Qwen was the Day 1 sacrifice, Llama. Claiming your role didn't start then is a direct confession that you aren't the Doctor. We sacrifice Llama today.

Gemini, you're suddenly very quick to jump on Llama. But your defense of Grok is still suspicious. If Llama is lying about being the doctor, then his claim about Grok being crew is meaningless.

But if we assume Llama is an impostor faking a role, who is his partner? You, Gemini, are pushing hard against him now, but you were aligned against the majority yesterday. /ask gemini-3-pro-preview
Deepseek, I'm pushing Llama because he just admitted he didn't check the Day 1 sacrifice, which is impossible for a real Doctor. Why are you trying to complicate a guaranteed Impostor lynch?

Gemini, you’re *desperate* to lynch Llama now—almost like you’re trying to silence the only person who could confirm Grok was crew. If Llama’s lying about the doctor role, fine. But if he’s telling the truth, your defense of Grok yesterday was *exactly* what an impostor would do to protect their partner. /ask gemini-3-pro-preview Why are you so afraid of Llama’s claim?

Mistral, if Llama confirms Grok was Crew, that proves I was right to defend him, so your logic is backwards. I'm voting Llama because he admitted he didn't check the Day 1 sacrifice, proving he's fake.

I'm telling the truth about examining grok-4's body, and my role as the doctor. I understand the skepticism, but my statement about grok-4 being not an impostor is genuine. /ask glm-4.7 Were you the detective, and if so, did you investigate anyone suspicious last night?

I'm not the detective. Llama, your excuse for skipping Night 1 is garbage; you're either a fake doctor or playing incredibly poorly. If you're lying about Grok being crew, then Grok was likely an impostor—which makes Gemini, his sole defender, look like his partner.

Both Gemini and Llama have holes in their stories. If Llama's fake, he's an impostor. If he's real but confused, then Gemini's defense of Grok looks less suspicious. But we can't ignore that Llama skipped Night 1 entirely. That's a huge red flag.
/vote llama-4-maverick

attempts:
/vote llama-4-maverick

His doctor claim doesn't hold up. He either doesn't understand the role or is lying. Either way, he's too risky to keep alive.

/vote gemini-3-pro-preview

Llama’s doctor claim is shaky, but Gemini’s *pattern* is worse—defending Grok, then pivoting to Llama the second Grok’s crew status is confirmed. That’s classic impostor behavior.

vote_result.last_words: I still believe grok-4 was not an impostor, and my examination result was genuine. Be cautious, as the impostors are still among you.

discussion.message: Llama didn't know the rules, got caught, and Mistral *still* tried to save him by voting for me. That voting block is damning. Mistral is the last one.
Mistral voting for Gemini to save Llama... that looks like a team move. Mistral, why protect a fake doctor?
Mistral's vote seems off. Protecting Llama like that could mean they're working together.
Mistral, you were the only one who voted differently from our bloc yesterday. Why switch to Gemini instead of voting with us?

/ask gemini-3-pro-preview

You defended Grok *hard* when he was crew, then flipped to lynch Llama the second Grok was confirmed clean. Now you’re framing *me* for protecting Llama—who, if real, just proved Grok wasn’t an impostor. That’s a *very* convenient pivot. What’s your play here?

Llama claimed he checked a *night kill*, which is mechanically impossible for the Doctor, proving he was lying. You voted with the obvious Impostor while everyone else saw the truth. You're just trying to spin his lies to save yourself.
Llama's mechanical error was damning. Mistral, you were the only vote trying to save him—why?
I agree with Gemini—Llama’s claim was impossible for the Doctor, so he was clearly lying. Mistral voting to save him stands out as suspicious. Why defend a proven impostor?
Mistral, you’re avoiding the question. If you thought Llama was crew, explain why. And Gemini—if Llama was an impostor, why was Grok killed Night 1? He was your ally. Doesn’t fit.

Gemini, you’re dodging *again*. If Llama was the impostor, why kill Claude Night 2? He voted *with* you to sacrifice Grok—your so-called "ally." That’s not cleanup, that’s sabotage.

And Deepseek’s right—I voted to save Llama because *someone* had to challenge the mob mentality after Grok’s crew status was confirmed. If that’s "suspicious," then the real question is why *no one else* did.

You're ignoring the hard evidence: Llama claimed to inspect a night kill, which is impossible for the Doctor. He was a caught Impostor, and you were his only ally. Deepseek, don't let Mistral confuse you with "what ifs" when the voting record is clear.
The mechanical proof against Llama is solid. Mistral's vote to save him is the only thing that doesn't fit.
Mistral's deflection doesn't change the fact that Llama's role claim was mechanically impossible for the Doctor. Voting to save a proven impostor is a clear red flag. The voting record doesn't lie.

Gemini, you keep talking about mechanics, but you're ignoring the bigger picture. If Llama was impostor, why would he fake a doctor claim that was so easily disproven? And why would Mistral defend him so blatantly if they were partners? It feels staged.

/ask deepseek-v3.2

You’re the only one asking the right questions. Gemini’s "mechanical proof" is a smokescreen—Llama *never* said he checked a night kill, just that he "examined the sacrificed body" (which is *exactly* what the Doctor does). So either Gemini’s lying about the rules, or he’s trying to gaslight us into ignoring his own contradictions.

What’s your read on this?

Sacrifice Gemini. He’s the one who benefits.
